ticket.title: [Feature Request] add :if / :unless conditions for attr_accessible, attr_protected and attr_readonly
ticket.original-body:
It would be very useful for organising state-driven behaviour for model.
Aim is ability to write code like this @@@ ruby with_options :if => :new? do |c| c.validates :date, :presence => true c.attr_accessor :city, :address end with_options :if => :confirmed? do |c| c.attr_accessible :nil c.attr_readonly :user_id end
def new? ... end def confirmed? ... end @@@
Discussion at state_machine lighthouse: http://pluginaweek.lighthouseapp.com/projects/13288/tickets/49-feature-request-activerecord-integration-state-driven-behaviour-of-attr_accessible-attr_protected-and-attr_readonly
ticket.latest-body:
It would be very useful for organising state-driven behaviour for model.
Aim is ability to write code like this @@@ ruby with_options :if => :new? do |c| c.validates :date, :presence => true c.attr_accessor :city, :address end with_options :if => :confirmed? do |c| c.attr_accessible :nil c.attr_readonly :user_id end
def new? ... end def confirmed? ... end @@@
Discussion at state_machine lighthouse: http://pluginaweek.lighthouseapp.com/projects/13288/tickets/49-feature-request-activerecord-integration-state-driven-behaviour-of-attr_accessible-attr_protected-and-attr_readonly
ticket.original-body-html:
It would be very useful for organising state-driven behaviour for model.

Aim is ability to write code like this

 with_options :if => :new? do |c|
  c.validates :date, :presence => true
  c.attr_accessor :city, :address
 end
 with_options :if => :confirmed? do |c|
  c.attr_accessible :nil
  c.attr_readonly :user_id
 end







 def new?
  ...
 end
 def confirmed?
  ...
 end

Discussion at state_machine lighthouse: http://pluginaweek.lighthouseapp.com/projects/13288/tickets/49-feat...

version.title: [Feature Request] add :if / :unless conditions for attr_accessible, attr_protected and attr_readonly

version.body: those methods are there to control mass-assignment. I cant see any use in deciding if mass-assignment is allowed or not by state. use case?
version.body-html: those methods are there to control mass-assignment. I cant see any use in deciding if mass-assignment is allowed or not by state. use case?
version.title: [Feature Request] add :if / :unless conditions for attr_accessible, attr_protected and attr_readonly

version.body:
Order created at two step "prebooking" and "book". At prebooking step user set only part of attributes (minimal set of attributes to check whether date is free). And then that attributes can't be changed, because we have limited quotes for hotel at day, and if bad man change, for example, date by mass-assignment we can get an hidden error.
@@@ with_options :if => :prebooking? do |c| c.attr_accessor :city, :hotel, :date end with_options :if => :book? do |c| c.attr_accessor :name, :phone, :email c.attr_readonly :city, :address, :date end @@@
version.body-html:
Order created at two step "prebooking" and "book". At prebooking step user set only part of attributes (minimal set of attributes to check whether date is free). And then that attributes can't be changed, because we have limited quotes for hotel at day, and if bad man change, for example, date by mass-assignment we can get an hidden error.

 with_options :if => :prebooking? do |c|
  c.attr_accessor :city, :hotel, :date
 end
 with_options :if => :book? do |c|
  c.attr_accessor :name, :phone, :email
  c.attr_readonly :city, :address, :date
 end
version.title: [Feature Request] add :if / :unless conditions for attr_accessible, attr_protected and attr_readonly

version.body: to deny changes of some attributes related to the current state validators should be used. i think you misuse those methods. they are only there to control mass-assignment, like in controllers.
version.body-html: to deny changes of some attributes related to the current state validators should be used. i think you misuse those methods. they are only there to control mass-assignment, like in controllers.
